FROM THE OUTER REACHES OF THE UNIVERSE

FROM THE MIDDLE OF THE MILKY WAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A million stars wink in the night desert sky. Down here o insect, one of those big, beautiful, multicolored four-wi effortlessly on the breeze, wafting along through the cri The insect dips, it banks, it does loop-the-loops -- and unceremoniously against the windshield of a white van tha the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DRIVER of the van, a fifty-year-old American, turns o smearing the remains all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn bugs. He squirts some wiper fluid onto the glass, which clears now he sees something worse up ahead. It's a grouping of of them, all pointed at him, sealing off the road. He bites his lip and calls over his shoulder, to the back speaks in Spanish, which is subtitled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deja me hablar. (Let me do the talking.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van slows to a stop in front of the parked cars, all four doors with "INS" stenciled on the sides. Seven or ei stand in front of the cars imposingly. Their apparent lea and comes to the window. The DRIVER rolls it down. AGENT JANUS, blonde-haired, blu government issue, looks at him and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. Nick the Dick. What a surprise. Where you comin' from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was fishing in Cuernavaca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you were. What do you say we have a look at your catch?

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BACK OF THE VAN,
dialogues.text: the Agents fling open the rear doors, revealing a DOZEN F MEXICANS, hopeful immigrants without official permission. looks at the Driver, who's now held by two other Agents, head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, I woulda thrown 'em back. (to the passengers, in Spanish)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vamanos. Fuera. Hagan una lina! (Let's go. Out. Form a line!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pile out of the van. Some are parents with small chi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you get, Nick? Hundred bucks a head?  Two hundred? I hope you saved it all for your lawyer, pal, 'cause you're gonna need -- He stops in the middle of his sentence, as another car is fast, its engine WHINING as it barrels down the road towa Agents pull their weapons. The new car pulls a hard right, goes off the road, spins cars, and SQUEALS to a sideways halt, silhouetted in fron headlights. It's a boxy, black 1986 Ford LTD. TWO MEN get out, dressed in plain black suits, crisp whit black ties, shiny black shoes. KAY, fiftyish, is the apot world-weary; his partner, DEE, mid-sixties, is just weary the INS agents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take it from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell are you? Kay and Dee flash some form of ID.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INS Division 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Division 6? I never heard of Division 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Kay and Dee move past him and approach the row of nervous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're we thinking, Dee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough call, Kay. He walks down the row, studying the faces, greeting each Spanish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: !Oye! Que pasa, coma estas? Hey! (What's up, how are you?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No se preocupe, abuela. Bienvenida a los Estados Unidos. (Don't worry grandma. Welcome to the United States.) (next)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A donde vas? San Antonio? Buscando trabajo, no? Buena suerta. (Where are you going? San Antonio?  Looking for work, aren't you?  Good luck.) (next)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Es un placer verle aqui. (It's a pleasure seeing you here.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One by one, their faces relax, reassured by Kay's calm de reaches the fifth Guy, he keeps the same cheery tone, but

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Que dices si te rompo la cara? (What do you say if I break your face?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guy smiles and nods. Kay stops. His own smile broaden hand on the Guy's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No hablas ni una palabra del Espanol, verdad, amigo? (You don't speak a word of Spanish, right, friend?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, the Guy smiles and nods. Kay looks back at Dee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a winner. (to the others)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Los restos estan libres a irse. Largense! (The rest of you are free to go. Scram!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomen el camion, y vayeuse. (Get on the road and go.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, you can't just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't "Sir" me! You have no idea who you're dealing with! Silence on the road. The Driver grins, jumps back in the van. The others pile into the rear and they tear out of t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Janus)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna have a little chat with our friend here. You boys can hit the road ... and keep on protecting us from dangerous aliens. Kay and Dee escort their captive across the road and over leaving the stunned INS agents standing alone in the road

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever heard of Division 6?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no Division 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are those guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay and Dee lead their captive into a clearing in the des pulls an enormous handgun from a shoulder holster and sta off, covering him. Kay has an arm draped around the man's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you jumped off the bus in the wrong part of town, amigo. In fact, I'll bet dollars to pesos that you're not -- He pulls out a small laser device, which he ZIPS neatly d the man's clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- from anywhere near here. The man's clothes fall to the ground, revealing what he r underneath -- A SCALY SPACE BASTARD, about four-and-a-hal a snouth, snail-like tentacles, and independently moving the top of his head. The only part of his camouflage not crumpled to the groun humanesque "head," which he still lamely holds in one of propped up by a stick, like a puppet, and it continues to as he holds it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikey?! When did they let you out of jail? MIKEY replies -- an unfathomable combination of GRUNTS, S saliva.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Political refugee. Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how many treaty articles you've just violated? Mikey makes a lame SQUEAK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One, my ass. Try seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From unauthorized immigration to failure to properly inoculate prior to landing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off Mikey's objections)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, that's enough. Hand me your head and put up your arms. From behind Mikey, they hear a terrified GASP. Kay and Dee both look over quickly. One of the alien's ey stalk, whips around too. All three of them see AGENT JANU over the rise, staring in frozen amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, shit. Agent Janus SCREAMS. Mikey rips free of the rest of the " disguise, knocks Dee out of the way, and takes off straig SCREECHING a horrible Space Bastard screech. Janus freeze

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dee! Shoot him! Dee struggles to roll over and change the controls on his out of his hand as he hit the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dee, for Christ's -- Mikey keeps moving, covering the last few yards to Janus on a rock, launches himself into the air, his dripping ja open -- -- there is a SIZZLING sound, a brilliant white flash -- -- and Mikey ERUPTS in a geyser of blue goo that splatter ground, the trees, and Agent Janus' face. Behind where Mi stands, smoking weapon in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the road, the INS AGENTS pull their guns and run towar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kay has an arm around Janus, whom he is leading further i Janus is white, shaking, eyes like silver dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Th -- th -- th --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "That."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't -- wasn't -- wasn't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Human, I know. Oops. Got some entrails on you. He takes out a handkerchief and wipes off the Agent's fac Janus looks back to where Mikey blew up. Then at Kay. And stars. The other INS Agents burst over the rise, SHOUTING questi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, everybody, situation's under control, calm down. If you'll just give me your attention for a moment I'll tell you what happened. From over the rise, car engines WHINE in the distance and to flash around them. Kay reaches into his pocket and pul metallic device the size of a pocket recorder. He checks figures in his head, then dials an electronic counter on device up to "08."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is called a "neuralyzer." A gift from some friends from out of town. The red eye here isolates and measures the electronic impulses in your brain. More specifically, the ones for memory. Behind him, six more MEN IN BLACK, all wearing black suit come over the hill. Kay barks a few orders to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme a splay burn on the perimeter, please; holes at 40, 60, and 80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in the hell is going on?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly the right question. And the answer lies right -- here. Pay attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you, really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? I'm just a figment of your imagination. He holds up the neuralyzer. The Agents peer closely at it into his pocket, puts on his own black sunglasses -- -- and pushes a button on the side of the neuralyzer.  A tenth of a second long sears the Agents' eyeballs. They s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, we're a gullible breed. Behind him, TONGUES OF FIRE blast from a flame thrower he Men in Black. Kay looks back at the INS Agents, who are j around, as if awakening from a concussion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean it, fellas, you are lucky to be alive after a blast like that. The Agents look around, confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What -- blast? Kay gestures behind him, where the Men in Black are now u extinguishers to douse the flames they themselves started

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Underground gas vein, genius. You guys need to exercise more caution before discharging your firearms. He jabs a finger into Janus' chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially you. Dee has moved away from them all and is sitting on a rock the night sky, his sunglasses dangling idly from one hand from the group and finds him. He sits down next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. About...back there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't used to. He holds up his hands, which tremble with age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spirit's willing, Kay, but the rest of me... He looks up, at the million stars shining overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're beautiful, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stars. We never just -- look. Anymore. (back to Kay)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell ya, Kay. I will miss the chase. Kay pulls his neuralyzer from his pocket and looks down a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shot of the clock on the Station's stately southern exp DOWN TO... A pair of feet running. They belong to a man we will know PERPETRATOR. As we track with him, he SPEEDS UP and OUT O A new set of feet come into frame. These belong to JAMES COP in undercover street clothes. In the BACKGROUND, abou behind, are two other cops, trying to keep up. Edwards is a lot faster, though. He pulls out his badge t chain under his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! NYPD! He continues running, out of frame, and we stay on one of overweight, who gives up the chase and drops to his knees

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All yours, Edwards! The Cop fumbles in his pocket for a pack of cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: TRACK WITH EDWARDS AND THE PERP
dialogues.text: As they run down the bridge that traverses Park Avenue in The Perp veers to the left and, seemingly oblivious to th a thirty-foot drop, he hurdles the guard rail, and drops Street below. EDWARDS is surprised by this maneuver, but doesn't waste too, hurdles the guard rail and lands on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DOUBLE-DECKER BUS, one of those cheesy sightseers that traffic. The bus, of course, is completely filled with JA and it seems like every single one of them has a video ca EDWARDS pushes through the crowd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grand Central Station off to your left, folks... With the bus still moving, he scrambles down the circular out through the side door. He spots the Perp, sailing east on Forty-first Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, man, you're making me sweat up my gear! Edwards spots one of those New York Post delivery trucks, the open back door, rumbling by.  He runs and jumps into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE PERP, meanwhile, is running at top speed, when Edward frame, leaning off the back of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, man, your luck just ran out. He leaps from the back of the moving truck and tackles th The Perp, now straddled by Edwards, is terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's coming! He's coming!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when he gets here, I'll kick his ass too. Edwards is about to slap the cuffs on him, when the Perp unusual about that, but then another set of translucent, eyelids, underneath his regular eyelids, blinks also. Edwards is thrown for a moment, which is all the time the pull out... His WEAPON, which is the strangest looking gun you've eve quickly, Edwards bats it out of the Perp's hand. THE WEAPON smashes into the stone wall surrounding Centra SHATTERS into a million pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the... WHOMP! The Perp kicks him in the nuts, then scrambles to takes off again. Edwards staggers after him, in pain. The Perp leaps over a moving car, towards the GUGGENHEIM tries to follow, but a bus pulls in front of him. After i Perp is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwards runs over to the Museum, leans over the wall that and in the next instant... The Perp flies past him, having leapt from twenty feet do the Guggenheim. He scrambles up and over the ledge. Edward reacts. He runs to the front door of the Museum, s runs inside. He runs from the rotunda up the grand ramp of the Guggenh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the roof, the PERP reaches the top, climbs over the ed to the gravel surface. He leaps to his feet and races ove locked. He tugs on another. It's locked too. He pulls on a third. -- revealing EDWARDS on the other side, breathing hard. H at the Perp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wassup? The Perp SCREAMS inhumanly and panics. He backpedals, tow the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's coming! He's coming because I failed, and now he'll kill me too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand. Your world is gonna end. But the Perp has backed right into the edge of the roof, to fall over. The Perp blinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you?! The Perp looks down. He decides. -- and he falls, SCREAMING, to his death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARDS sits on one side of the table, a POLICE INSPECTOR SERGEANT (the one who gave up the chase and lit a cigaret across from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perpetrator then blinked two sets of eyelids. You mean blinked with both eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. He blinked once with one set, then again with another completely different set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sort of a low beam, high beam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that before or after he drew the weapon which you claim evaporated into a million pieces?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why do you suppose none of the other officers saw either of these two events?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause some of the other officers are a little soggy in the midsection. And they couldn't keep up, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Edwards, if you were half the man I am --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? I am half the man you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is your problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My problem is you being all up in my damn face all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he threw him off the roof. Ten minutes -- your best shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting off the Sergeant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant. I want to talk to you outside. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need ten minutes on a Stairmaster, you pudgy bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman sneaks into the room. DOCTOR LAUREL WEAVER, thirt dark-haired, dark-eyed, general aura of darkness around h him. Laurel looks like she was just dragged out of bed (w saw a spaceman (which she did).  She looks over her shoul whispers to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurel Weaver. Deputy Medical Examiner. I believe you. I opened him up. Find me at the morgue. On 26th. I'll tell you what I found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey...Wait a minute. Wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning at the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have really pretty eyes. She hurries to turn the corner, but is STOPPED by someone offscreen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Weaver, from the coroner's office? Working on the John Doe? Edwards twists in his chair, to get a better look. All he facing whoever it is in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you look right here, please. The Someone says something else and Laurel steps forward, Edwards's line of vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look where? Edwards stretches even further in his seat, when there is from the corridor. Really curious now, he starts to get u -- when KAY steps into the room and closes the door behin rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some night, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, some night. He crosses to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were gills. Edwards stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not eyelids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he say anything to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scoffing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. He said the world was coming to an end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he say when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you recognize his weapon if you saw it again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take a ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. I got a ton of paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all done. At that point, the INSPECTOR sticks his head in, smiles a the thumbs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good work, Edwards. Edwards looks at the Inspector, then at Kay. As they leav

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ran that guy down on foot? That's tough. That's double tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a plain, boxy Ford, Kay drives, silent. He raises his a black MIB truck coming in the opposite direction.Edward passenger seat, is still in his undercover outfit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So who you with? Kay says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got the plain clothes, the government-issued wheels. Secret Service?

dialogues.speaker: CIA
dialogues.text: Kay remains utterly silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring to the car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, whoever it is, you're short on funding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing is what it seems, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, my bad '86 Ford LTD. That's a luxury ride. C'mon, who ya with? Kay pulls the car to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm part of a secret organization that monitors and polices alien activity on earth. Kay opens the door and gets out of the car. Edwards follo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwards looks around. Sees they're standing in front of a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is where we're going? They get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Jeebs? Guy buys from chain snatchers. Doesn't even sell guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, you think it's worth shaking him up, fine. I'll do my thing. Then I want some answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do your "thing," kid.  Edwards goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK JEEBS is the sleazy, sarcastic proprietor of the Paw easily intimidated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer Edwards. Oh, hey, geez, how'd these get here? I thought I turned 'em in to the proper authorities. He casually brushes some Rolexes off the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Way I hear it, Jeebs, you into something a little hotter than some stolen Rolexes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure -- I'm a big crack dealer now. I just work here because I love the hours. This pisses Edwards off. He grabs Jeebs by the collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting angry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about guns, Jeebs. High-tech stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Edwards, whatcha see is what I got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you show him the imports, Jeebs. At the sound of Kay's voice, Jeebs suddenly pales, a look over his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: H-hiya Kay, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The imports, Jeebs. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I got outta that business a long time ago, Kay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you lie to me? I hate it when you lie. He pulls his own gun and aims it at Jeebs' forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, Kay, hold on a minute here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to count to three. Edwards, seeing that Kay is getting somewhere, joins in t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll do it, Jeebs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen him do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to me, Jeebs, he's crazy when he's like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's always crazy. (to Kay)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a cruise. Get a massage --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three. KA-BOOM! Kay blows Jeebs' head off and Jeebs' body collap Edwards is shocked. Edwards pulls his own weapon and points it at Kay's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put down the gun and put your hands on the counter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I warned him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop the weapon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You warned him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are under arrest. You have the right to remain silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you relax?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do that. Edwards whirls around to see Jeebs' BODY, growing another four or five seconds. Kay calmly shoves his gun up agains baby-soft new cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how much that hurts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show us what you got, Jeebs. Or I'll use up another one. Jeebs, panicked, hits a button on the underside of the co promptly flips over, revealing yet another dusty shelf, p junk -- -- but this is all alien junk. Weapons, mostly, bizarre, weapons of all shapes and sizes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwards? Edwards, still dazed by Jeebs' regrown head, glances down weapons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, this. This is what I saw. Kay looks at Jeebs, pissed off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sold a carbonizer with implosion capacity to an unlicensed cephlapoid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looked all right to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A carbonizer is an assassin's weapon, Jeebs. Who was the target?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Kay raises the weapon again, threatening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeebs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know! Kay lowers his gun, gestures to the shelf full of weapons

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all confiscated. All of it. I want you on the next transport off this rock. Or I'll shoot you where it doesn't grow back. Jeebs nods, point taken. Kay leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'll be by tomorrow for those Rolexes. Shaken, Edwards follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwards staggers out of the shop, trying to get the day's in his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eyelids, fine ... and the jumping thing ... and the gun ... okay, but the head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Searching for a handle on the moment here? A place to file all this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See a head doesn't do that, it doesn't just grow back. (looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't help you, kid. Only comfort I can offer is that tomorrow, you won't remember a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. This I'm gonna remember for a long, long time. Kay pulls the neuralyzer from his pocket. He hesitates fo moments -- as if this particular neuralyzation is differe others. Then he puts on his sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever see one of these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the flash dims on EDWARDS and KAY, sitting at a table restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finishing a joke)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and the wife says yeah, Harry, I know, but this one's eating my popcorn! He busts out laughing. Edwards, across from him, is compl disoriented. He looks down. There's a half-eaten order of and several empty bottles of beer on the table in front o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Kay checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoops. Gotta run. Thanks for the egg rolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what I mean about tequila? You're a bright young man, James. Just lay off the sauce. I'll see you tomorrow, nine a.m. sharp. He turns and walks out. Edwards checks his watch. A WAITR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee. Please. She walks off. Edwards looks at the table. There is a bus next to his plate, on which Kay has handwritten "James D. Saturday, 9 a.m., 504 Battery Drive." Edwards looks at it, puzzled. He turns the card over and other side. There's not much there, no name, no phone or e-mail address. Just three little letters, dead in the mi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lonely farmhouse stands amid the fields of upstate New country. Several lights are on and through a window we ca silhouette of a MAN sitting at the kitchen table, the sil WOMAN hovering over him, bringing things to him. The Man (EDGAR) waves his arms, ranting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I go out, I work my butt off to make a living, all I want is to come home to a nice clean house with a nice fat steak on the table, but instead I get this -- this -- I don't even know what you call this! In the sky above, it's one of those brilliant star fields strange is happening with one of those stars -- it's gett

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what it looks like, it looks like poison. Don't you take that away, I'm eating that, damn it! It is poison, isn't it?! No, that star isn't getting bigger, it's moving. Toward u from a pinpoint to a dime, to a nickel, to a quarter, and into fruit metaphors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to God, I would not be surprised if it was, the way you skulk around here like a dog been hit too much -- or ain't been hit enough, I can't make up my mind. Okay, we're way past watermelon now, that thing is huge, to glow hot red as it enters the earth's atmosphere, head toward us, coming here, to Beatrice and Edgar's place. The blazing fireball barrels through the sky, SNAPS off a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're useless, Beatrice! The only thing that pulls its weight around here is my goddamn truck! -- and SLAMS right through a pickup truck parked in the d concussive BLAST follows, then a geyser of smoke and flam

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay here! The silhouette of Edgar leaps to its feet, races to the d it open. Edgar is everything his voice led us to expect - bug-eyed redneck carrying a twelve-gauge shotgun. His mou walks across the yard and stares at the hulking shell tha The skeleton of the truck is still there, but there's a h hole in it, a hole that goes at least ten feet down into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figures. He walks to the truck and touches the door handle. Hot. U tail, he opens the door and peers down into the hole. IN THE HOLE, he sees a smooth curve of metal and a few bl Embedded into the ground is, indeed, a spaceship, maybe e BEATRICE calls from behind him, standing in the doorway f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Edgar?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your big butt back in that house! Beatrice does as she's told, closing the door behind her. to the smoldering rock, raising his shotgun in defense. A VOICE comes from deep in the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Place projectile weapon on ground. Edgar staggers back a step, terrified. But then he regain the weapon, and steps forward, pointing it menacingly dow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can have my gun when you pry it from my cold, dead fingers! There is a pause while the voice thinks about this offer. responds, in a voice and cadence remarkably similar to Ed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your proposal is acceptable. A long, hairy pincer flashes out of the hole, grabs Edgar pulls him down into the hole. From deep in the hole, we hear a terrible RIPPING sound, being torn in half. There are some disgusting GUSHY sound later, something flies out of the hole and FLOPS onto the the truck. It's Edgar. Well, sort of. His body parts still hang toge arms, legs, even clothes -- but everything inside has bee he just lies there, flat and empty, like a tuxedo on the prom. The shotgun flies out and lands beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEATRICE sits at the kitchen table, terrified, still wipi from Edgar's diatribe. The door opens and EDGAR comes bac kitchen, seemingly fleshed out again, leaving the door ha him. He carries the shotgun. She looks up at him, anxious. But his face is a blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What on earth was it?! He looks at her strangely. When he speaks, his voice is d before. More refined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar. Pause. She looks out the window, at the smoking truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never seen sugar do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me sugar. Puzzled, Beatrice gets up, goes to the cabinet, and grabs She holds it out to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In water. Frightened, she takes a glass of water from the table. Sh the sugar into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More. She puts more, till the glass is brimming. She stirs it q knife and hands it to him, her hand trembling. Edgar takes it and downs it in a single gulp. Beatrice st idea what to think. She notices something odd about the s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar, your skin! It's -- it's -- just hanging off your bones! Edgar drops the glass and looks in a window, to catch his reaches up -- -- and twists his whole face, as if adjusting a ski mask, skin of his neck back into his shirt collar.  He looks at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That better? Beatrice faints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stillness. Silence. A loud SCRAPING sound comes from the spaceship. The nose of the ship itself rises up out of the pit, wave and finally CRUNCHES to the ground outside the pit. EDGAR climbs out of the pit, breathing heavily. He dusts continues pushing the ship, along the ground, off into th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning. EDWARDS, holding the small MIB business hand, compares the address written down by Kay to the add utterly nondescript building in front of him. It's seven gray, windowless, perfectly square, squatting on a bridge a fat guy on the john. "504 Battery Drive."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARDS steps through a heavily barred metal door and int room. One wall is entirely dominated by the enormous blad vent air intake. There is an elevator at the far end of t OLD SECURITY GUARD, the rent-a-cop kind, reading a comic metal chair halfway across. Edwards walks across the room, his footsteps ECHOING. The

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, I'm not sure, see, I got this card --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elevator. Push the "call" button. And he goes back to his comic book. Edwards, maybe out of than curiosity at this point, walks across the room, towa As he draws close, the elevator doors WHOOSH open, expect

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwards steps inside and turns around. The doors close. H "call" button and waits, but the elevator doesn't move. I the other side of the elevator slide open silently behind waits, unaware. From behind him, somebody clears their throat. Edwards tu finds himself standing in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This back room is every bit as mysterious and unfamiliar Standing at the front of the room is ZED, a wire-haired c old school bureaucrat, wearing the exact same kind of sui night. SIX OTHER HOT RECRUITS sit in egg-shaped chairs, s Edwards. One chair is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late. Sit down. Edwards takes the remaining chair. The elevator doors sli continues addressing the Recruits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Zed. You're all here because you're the best of the best. Marines, Navy SEALS, Army Rangers...NYPD. They all turn and regard Edwards a little smugly. He give

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we're looking for one of you. Just one. What will follow is a series of simple tests designed to quantify motor skills, hand-eye coordination, concentration, stamina -- I see we have a question. Edwards's hand is, indeed, up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, uh -- I'm sorry, it's just no one really asked this, but -- why, exactly, are we doing this? Silence. Then one of the young recruits eagerly raises hi on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud and formal)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake Jensen, West Point, graduate with honors. We're here because you're looking for the best of the best of the best, sir! Edwards tries to stifle a laugh, but can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so funny, Edwards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- I don't know, sir. This guy. "Best of the best of the best of the best of the --" (realizing nobody is with him on this)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just struck me as -- (totally serious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Humorous. Sir. Short pause. Then Zed continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's get going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The recruits scribble away at the written test. It's a th reasoning skills, general knowledge, diagrams.  The RECRU really powering through it, filling in answer after answe But no desks have been provided for them, and they're all chairs, writing uncomfortably on their thighs or knees. EDWARDS is really struggling. He writes two words on one decides to erase it. The lack of a writing surface is dri his pencil even TEARS through the page. He looks up. In the middle of the tile floor, there is an Edwards gets up, goes to it, grabs hold -- -- and drags it, SCREECHING DEAFENINGLY, back to his chai looks up, wincing at the horrible sound that fills the ro Edwards sits back down, now writing on the table.  That's Zed raises an eyebrow. He stares at Edwards, then looks u smoked glass window. Behind the dark glass, a FIGURE stan unemotional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEVEN WEAPONS rest on a table in the middle of an otherwi triangular room. The SEVEN RECRUITS stand in front of the There's an odd moment -- where everyone sort of looks aro other, at the blank walls...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone, uh...any of you guys know what we're doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clipped, unquestioning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking for the best of the best of the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (can't help but smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yeah, I know, but... And then .. suddenly -- The two far walls pull apart. The whole room pulsates and suddenly filled with a bewildering swirl of stroboscopic human and alien. Everywhere is color, light and movement mass of strange shapes and characters moving simultaneous The Recruits lunge for the weapons, snapping them up and SHOTS are fired at once. And then, a second later, a SEVE fired. Everyone sort of looks at Edwards, who puts his gu There's an awkward silence. Then the door opens. Light po with it. Even the highly competitive cadets can't help bu sympathy as Zed walks straight to Edwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hesitated, sir. Zed looks into the gallery. Most obvious in the frozen ta creatures is a lunging, snarling beast, which has three b its chest. Next to it is a massively deformed humanoid cr large hook for a head, which also has three holes in it. corner of the gallery, there is a single bullet hole in a eight-year-old girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I ask why you felt little Tiffany deserved to die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was the only one who actually seemed dangerous. At the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how did you come to that conclusion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hook-head guy. You explain to me how he can think with a hook for a head. Answer; it's not his head. His head is that butt-ugly bean-bag thing over there. 'Cause if you look at the snarling beast-guy, he's not snarling, he's sneezing -- he's got tissues in his hand. No threat there, and anyhow, the girl's books were way too advanced for an eight-year-old's. And besides, from where I'm looking, she was the only one who appeared to have a motive. And I don't appreciate your jumping down my throat about it. Sideways glances from the other recruits. Zed sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or, uh -- do I owe her an apology?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZED and KAY stand behind smoked glass, staring at the REC still in the shooting gallery, waiting for a decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a real problem with authority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do I. The guy ran down a cephlapoid, Zed. On foot. Tenacity. That I can use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you know what you're doing. Zed turns and walks away. Kay stares through the glass, a stands alone on one side of the room, apart from the rest Zed reappears on the other side of the glass, coming thro into the shooting gallery. As he talks, Kay turns and wal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations, you're everything we've come to expect from years of government training. Now, if you'll just follow me, we have one more test to administer, an eye exam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RECRUITS follow ZED out of the shooting gallery and i hallway. Zed motions them off to the left. EDWARDS is the the room, but he stops as he steps into the hallway. KAY is outside the door, waiting for him. Edwards recogni night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You! Hey, what's goin' on? The other recruits continue down the hall with Zed. Kay d just gestures to Edwards to follow him down the hall, whi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the mid-fifties, the government started a little underfunded agency with the simple and laughable purpose of making contact with a race not of this planet. As they pass an alcove, Edwards notices the six other Rec been herded into a corner. Zed, addressing them, pulls a his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, if you'll look directly at the end of this device. He holds a neuralyzer up in front of them, and the Recrui obediently at it as Zed slips on a pair of black sunglass Edwards stares, fascinated, but Kay's hand reaches in and just as Zed's neuralyzer FLASHES WHITE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As KAY leads EDWARDS down an impossibly long corridor, he folder stuffed thick with eight by ten photographs. He hands Jay the first picture, a shot of eight or nine M suits standing around a fifties-style office with metal d fluorescent lights. DEE and ZED are there, much younger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody thought the agency was a joke. Except the aliens. They made contact on March 2nd, 1961, outside New  York City. Another photograph, a grainy black and white image of two in the night sky -- classic flying saucer shapes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were nine of us that night. Seven agents. An amateur astronomer. And one poor kid who got lost on the wrong back road. Yet another photograph, this one showing a young KAY, in holding a bouquet of flowers, staring at the open door of flying saucer. ALIEN SHAPES are visible within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You brought the aliens flowers? Kay steers Edwards to the right, down another corridor, j the first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were intergalactic refugees with a simple request. Let us use the earth as an apolitical zone for people without a planet.  Ever see "Casablanca?" Same thing, no Nazis.  We agreed. So we masked all evidence of their landing. Another picture, this one of the 1964 World's Fair ground construction. Giant models of rockets mark the Fair's the travel; most prominent in the construction are two tall t flying saucers now mounted at the top of each.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 1964 World's Fair was a coverup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why else would we hold it in Queens? (another hallway)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now left. More nonhumans arrive every year. They live among us, in secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. Not to change the subject, but when was your last cat-scan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every six months; it's company policy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thanks for the very amusing morning, but I'm hopin' you'll show me where I came in?  'Cause this is where I go out. They have stopped next to an unmarked door. Kay throws it inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure, hang on, I wanna grab a coffee while we're right here. As Kay walks into the kitchenette, Edwards' jaw drops, hi he stares in wonderment -- -- at THREE WORM-LIKE ALIENS standing around a water cool impossibly thin, most certainly not from New York, the al animated conversation in a language that seems like a com Esperanto and microphone feedback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the aliens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me we've only got that powdered shit for cream again? One of the Worm Aliens answers him in their native tongue the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. He finds the cream sitting out on the counter where the a dumps some in his coffee, and comes back outside, closing him. He reaches up and gently pushes Edwards' jaw up, clo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For future reference, this is a better look for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARDS, thrown for a major loop, sits like a zombie alon bench in Battery Park. Kay drinks his coffee while they t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any given time, around fifteen hundred landed aliens are on the planet, the majority right here in Manhattan. Most aliens are decent enough, just trying to make a living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cab drivers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as many as you'd think. Humans, for the most part, don't have a clue. Don't want one, either. They're happy. They think they've got a pretty good bead on things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the big secret? People are smart, they can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A person is smart. People are dumb. Everything they've ever "known" has been proven to be wrong. A thousand years ago everybody knew as a fact, that the earth was the center of the universe. Five hundred years ago, they knew it was flat. Fifteen minutes ago, you knew we humans were alone on it. Imagine what you'll know tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the catch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you'll gain in perspective, you'll lose in ways you're too young to comprehend. You give up everything. Sever every human contact. No one will know you exist. Ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not even allowed a favorite shirt. There.  That's the speech I never heard. That's the choice I never got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold up. You track me down, put me through those stupid-ass tests, now you're trying to talk me out of it. I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got 'til sun-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it worth it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You find out, you let me know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost nighttime now, and the park is empty. EDWARDS is s bench. And still thinking. Above him, the stars are comin Slowly, he looks up, into the vastness of the heavens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning. A door opens on a garage and an ORKIN M carrying a tank of toxic gas. The morning light spills on spiders, crawling everywhere -- big ones, small ones, hun have moved in and taken over this dusty place. The Orkin Man sighs and sets down his tank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, well. Movin' right in, are we? Think we own the place? He unfurls a hose from the side of the tank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a little eviction notice for you, boys. He raises a mask to his face and unscrews the handle on t tank. LETHAL GAS starts to HISS from the end of the hose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what exactly do you think you're doing? The Orkin Man turns around. EDGAR stands in the doorway t staring at him disdainfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Takin' care of your pest problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Pest" problem? "Pest?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. You got a hell of an infestation. Edgar advances on him, slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I have noticed an infestation here. Everywhere I look, in fact. Nothing but undeveloped, unevolved, barely conscious pond scum. So convinced of their own superiority as they scurry about their short, pointless lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- yeah. Don't you want to get rid of 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the worst way. Edgar lashes out quickly, jerking the mask off the Orkin one hand -- -- and shoving the gas hose down his throat with the othe THE ORKIN MAN'S CAR KEYS drop to the garage floor, and Ed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A six-by-ten sheet of plywood THUDS to the driveway outsi EDGAR raises one end of it so it's hanging off the back e man's van -- now it's a ramp. He walks off and we hear that familiar SCRAPING sound aga GRUNTING with the effort, slowly pushes his spaceship up the back of the Orkin truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARDS stands in the middle of the tunnel vent room, the first came into yesterday. The elevator doors open and KA summoned by the OLD SECURITY GUARD, stands waiting for hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing you gotta know right now. Edwards walks briskly forward and gets in the elevator wi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the elevator, the doors WHOOSH shut, KAY turns a k floor number, and the descent begins. EDWARDS continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I'm in because there's some next-level shit going on around here, and I'm with that. Before you beam me up, there are a couple of things we need to get straight. You chose me 'cause you recognize the skills. So as of now you can cease with all of that calling me "son" or "kid" or "sport." Cool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool, slick. Now about those skills of yours, The elevator doors --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- slide open on Men in Black headquarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As of this moment, they don't mean much. It's unlike anything we've ever seen -- huge, multilevele design, polished steel and glass. The workplaces are slee uncluttered, manned by both HUMANS and ALIENS. Most of th the background, like the UPSIDE-DOWN GUY who walks on the shuffling papers. KAY and EDWARDS step off the elevator and onto a platform over the whole place. Kay leads him down into the complex. First, they walk pas passport control center, where a human BUREAUCRAT at a de the documents of a line of ALIENS who've just arrived. Th bizarre life forms in that line, CHATTING in half a dozen tongues. Edwards slows as they pass, listening to the PASSPORT CON he addresses an ARQUILLIAN, a large, humanoid visitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Purpose of trip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diplomatic mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duration of stay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carrying any fruits or vegetables? Edwards just stares, fascinated, but Kay grabs him by the him along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go. He's a little...grouchy. Kay moves him into the central hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of hours wait after a 17-light-year flight would get on anybody's nerves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What branch of the government do we report to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None. They started asking too many questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So who pays for all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we hold a few patents on gadgets we confiscated from our out-of-state visitors. Velcro. Microwave Ovens. Liposuction. AT A STORAGE CAGE, Kay turns a key in the lock of a caged throws the door open. Inside, there are piles of sophisti devices stacked on shelves and tabletops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking something up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. A new recording device to replace CD's.  So now I gotta buy the White Album again? (something else)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is amusing. Universal translator. He holds up a cylindrical metal tube and a small wire cli a lapel microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not supposed to have it. I'll tell you why.  Human thought is so primitive it's considered an infectious disease. Makes you proud, doesn't it? Edwards picks up a small yellow ball from one of the shel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch that! THE BALL ZINGS OUT OF EDWARDS' HANDS -- it flies out into -- hits the ceiling and ricochets around the room, faster follow -- VARIOUS SHOTS OF HUMANS AND ALIENS ducking, dodging, and its way. ON KAY as he calmly, a little wearily, slips an odd-looki over his right hand... He raises his hand and the yellow ball zings into it -- K ball, calmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caused the '77 New York blackout. Practical joke by the Great Attractor. He thought it was funny as hell. They leave the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry! ON THE MAIN FLOOR, they walk briskly across the room, rea screen on the far wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Observation, the heart of our little endeavor. The screen displays a map of the world on which thousands blink in all parts of the globe, log lines of data flashi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This map shows the location of every registered alien on earth at any given time. Some of them we keep under constant surveillance. He hits a button on the console and the map is replaced b boxes, each with smaller video images.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone on these screens is an alien. In public -- normal. In private -- you'll get the idea. ON THE SCREENS, we see live images of aliens. Aliens who spots where they can't be seen.  Aliens who look human ar right out in public -- including SAM DONALDSON. MICHAEL J ROBBINS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet the twins. Kay gestures to two small, bony CREATURES with eight arms single eye growing out of a central stalk in their heads. and wave two or three arms each.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta be honest about something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes no sense?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes perfect sense. When I was a third grader in Philadelphia, they told me I was crazy 'cause I swore that our teacher was from, like, Venus or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Edelson. Edwards, stunned, looks at Kay as 4-Eyes boots her onto t face, cat glasses. Bony fingers. Extremely well-hidden ta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jupiter, actually. Well, one of the moons. With their remaining arms, they punch button after button console. ZED, who was standing up close to the screen, wa Edwards, sizing him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your jacket size, Edwards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh -- forty regular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's put it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put what on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last suit you'll ever wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the rest of the place, the MIB locker room is all wh white floor, white ceiling, white lockers. ZED'S VOICE co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From now on, you'll dress only in attire specially sanctioned by MIB Special Services. EDWARDS reaches out and opens a white locker, revealing a from a hanger in the middle. Above it, on the shelf, a BL pair of BLACK SUNGLASSES. On the bottom, a pair of SHINY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAY is at a computer terminal. On screen are Edwards's bi driver's license, social security card, library card, eve VOICE continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll conform to the identity we give you, eat where we tell you, live where we tell you, get approval for any expenditure over a hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EDWARDS stands in a cramped white booth. He holds both his hands on a TEN-FINGERED KEYPAD, pressin pad glows red, a SEARING sound comes from his hands, and more lasers instantly and (not at all) painlessly change

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will have no identifying marks of any kind.  You will not stand out in any way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One by one, KAY deletes Edwards's identity cards. On the computer screen is Edwards' full name -- JAMES DAR Kay punches a couple keys, and the cursor begins to sweep left, starting to eliminate the rightmost letters of Edwa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your entire image is carefully crafted to leave no lasting memory whatsoever with anyone you encounter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pants come off the hanger. The white shirt is removed. More letters are eliminated from his name. It reads "JAME then "JAMES DARR..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a rumor, recognizable only as deja vu and dismissed just as quickly. You don't exist; you were never even born. The coat is removed. The hat comes off the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anonymity is your name. Silence your native tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are no longer part of "the system." We're above the system. Over it. Beyond it. Feet slip into black shoes. A belt is buckled. A tie push

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're "them." We're "they." On screen, all that's left is the letter "J." As the coat is buttoned, we notice the sleeve. Monogramme simply, the letter "J."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are the Men in Black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking slick and handsome in his extremely sharp suit, J III -- or, rather, JAY -- steps into the doorway from the reaches into his pocket, takes out the sunglasses, and lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The difference between you and me? He slips on the sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I make this look good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are looking at a telephoto shot of Manhattan in all it We see the Orkin van topping a hill, heading towards Manh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zed's office is a circular, windowed room elevated above MIB headquarters. JAY and KAY sit across the desk from Ze video monitors on a wall behind Zed's desk, and on each m Man in Black, in different parts of the world, the city n ticking in a corner of the image. While Zed talks, he goes through paperwork on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's see. (to one of the monitors)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bee, we got the deposed sur-prefect of Sinalee touching down in the forest outside Portland tonight. I'm pulling you down from Anchorage to do a meet-and-greet. BEE, an agent on one of the monitors, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Humanoid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wish. Bring a sponge. (going through memos)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else -- everybody, we gotta keep Rolling Fish-Goat out of the sewer system, he's scaring the rats. And Bobo the Squat wants to reveal himself on "Unsolved Mysteries." Bee, make sure he doesn't. He turns a page, coming across a red memo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red-letter from last night -- we had an un-authorized landing somewhere in upstate New York farm country. Keep your ears open for this one, Kay, we're not hosting a galactic kegger down here. Next to him, his computer screen BEEPS importantly.  Zed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, well -- we got a skimmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jay)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Landed alien out of zone. (to Zed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redgick. He's not cleared to leave Manhattan but he's way out of town right now, stuck in traffic on the New Jersey Turnpike. Why don't you take Jay? This is a good one for him to warm up on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAY and KAY come out the front of MIB headquarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, wussup with Zed? (imitating him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Go get em, tiger. We're not hosting an intergalactic kegger..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zed was saving the world before you were born, son. Show some respect. An MIB MECHANIC pulls up in Kay's black LTD and hops out, open. Jay sizes up the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got the use of unlimited technology from the entire universe and we cruise around in this? Kay glares at Jay. He's getting annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get in and slam the doors. Kay starts the car and th quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seat belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, ya'll gotta learn how to talk to people. You could be a little kinder and gentler. Kay grits his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buckle up, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now did that hurt? Kay shifts the car into reverse. The awesome power of the Jay sails forward, THWACKING into the dash. Kay shifts in taps the gas, SLAMMING Jay back into his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makin' fun of my ride... A LIGHTED PANEL rotates into place between the two front hand falls by accident on a flashing red button in the pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jay. The button?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never push the button, Jay. Jay jerks his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LTD is now stopped by the side of the road, dust swir Ahead of it, another car has pulled over. KAY gets out, J moment later, shaky-legged. Kay walks up to the window of stopped. The DRIVER, a guy in his mid-thirties with a WIF mid-thirties, rolls the window down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: License and registration, please. The Driver hands over some documents. Kay flips through t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other license and registration, please. The guy digs out two other cards and hands those over. Ja Kay's shoulder. The photographs on the "RESIDENT ALIEN ID"cards are of tw friendly-looking reptile types, husband and wife, smiling their long, skinny tongues dangling in a friendly sort of Kay hands them back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your resident card has you restricted to the five boroughs only. Where do you think you're going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my wife! She's -- she's -- well, look! Kay leans down and looks in the window. MRS. REDGICK is i in pain, holding her swollen belly. Kay straightens up, f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God. How soon? Mrs. Redgick SCREAMS in pain. Real soon. For the first ti seen him, Kay is nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. All right. No big deal. (to Jay)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You handle it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, it's easy, you just sorta -- catch. Mrs. Redgick SCREAMS again. Redgick gets out of the car,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure he knows what he's doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, hell, sure, he does this all the time. C'mon, let him work, Redgick, I wanna ask you something. Kay gives Jay a supportive SLAP on the back and leads Red rear of the car. Jay stays in the background and opens th tentatively. He leans down, into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God! I see it I see it I see it! A few yards from the car, Kay turns Redgick to face him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Croagg the Midwife's back on 64th and 8th. You were headed out of town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we're, uh -- meeting someone. Suddenly a TENTACLE whips out from between Mrs. Redgick's whip once, and wraps around the door post, grabbing hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sweet Jesus Mother of God did you see that?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still to Redgick)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? Who you meeting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's -- a ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? I didn't see a departure clearance for today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't? Uh, well -- it was an emergency. Now a SECOND TENTACLE whips out, but this one wraps aroun pulls tight. He GASPS, choking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys -- guys --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doin' fine, Ace. (back to Redgick)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of emergency? What's the rush to get off the planet all of a sudden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (choking to death)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help?! HELP! Hello?! He starts tugging for all he's worth, but the fight is so against him, as the tentacles pull him in even harder tha pull the baby out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just don't like the neighborhood anymore. Some of the -- new arrivals. Redgick looks at Kay, clearly concealing something, but d away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What new arrivals? This have anything to do with the crasher from last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you guys do this later?! But in that moment, Jay finally gets a foot up on the doo leverage, and RIPS the baby free. He falls, flat on his b the multi-tentacled lizardlike baby resting squarely on h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh -- oh -- oh -- man. Kay turns and claps Redgick on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations! It's a lizard. Jay looks down at the creature COOING and nestling on his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (misty)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you know, it is sorta -- It vomits on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the car, JAY wipes the last of the puke off his s starts up the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything about that seem unusual to you? Jay just looks at him, very Jack Benny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of "new arrival" would scare Redgick so bad that he'd risk a warp jump with a newborn? (thinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's check the hot sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON on various supermarket tabloids as a hand flips There are headlines like "POPE A FATHER!"and "TOP DOCTORS BORN PREGNANT!" and "MAN EATS OWN HOUSE!" (the subhead on That's Just the Appetizer, Says Neighbor.") KAY and JAY are at a downtown newsstand. Kay is furiously through the tabs; Jay is standing behind him, a little em

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are the hot sheets? Kay pulls a copy of the Weekly World News from the stand a buck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best damn investigative reporting on the planet.  But hey, go ahead, read the New York Times if you want. They get lucky sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're actually looking for tips in a supermarket tabloid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not looking for. Found. He SMACKS the paper down on the hood in front of Jay, the open to a headline in typeface so large one would think i the Second Coming: Farm wife says "ALIEN STOLE MY HUSBAND'S SKIN!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flap of skin, now getting gray and crusty with age, han neck as he sits in the front of his Orkin van. He sucks a possibly can on a straw stuck into a Jolt Cola ("Double t the Caffeine!"), one of a six-pack that sits on the dashb Across the street, Edgar sees a short, older man come out jewelry shops on Thirty-Fifth Street. Edgar drops the sod The Older Man (ROSENBERG), is carrying a cat and an ornat jewelry box. Carefully, he sets the box down and lovingly on top of it while he locks all five locks on the door to shop. That finished, he picks up the cat, then the box, then wa the street, one under each arm. Edgar drops the truck into gear and follows him, slowly, behind him. ON THE STREET, Rosenberg walks happily along, HUMMING to his cat a little peck. As he rounds a corner, we recogniz humming -- "I've Got the Whole World In My Hands." The Orkin van rounds the corner behind him. Following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LTD pulls to a stop at the end of the driveway that l Beatrice's farmhouse, where the alien ship landed. The wr truck is still there. JAY and KAY get out, very undercove up the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so fast. Walk up slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Part of the routine. Makes it look like we're sizing up the situation. Gives her time to get the wrong impression. BEATRICE appears in the door to the house, curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puts some fear into her. Makes things go smoother. Beatrice calls to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you gentlemen? Beatrice looks much better than the last time we saw her dressed, a touch of makeup, a smile on her face. Kay pulls a black card from his wallet and extends it to close. As she reaches for it, the card reforms into an FB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, ma'am, I'm Special Agent Manheim, this is Agent Black, FBI. Had a few questions about your visitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you here to make fun of me too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ma'am. We at the FBI don't have a sense of humor that we're aware of. Mind if we come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Lemonade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the living room, KAY sips some of her lemonade and win through the room, checking it out as BEATRICE tells her s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they said to me, "If he was murdered, how could he walk back in the house?" And I must admit, I was a little stumped by that one. But I know Edgar. And that wasn't him. It was more like something else that was wearing him. Like a suit. An Edgar suit. A little GIGGLE escapes her at the thought. Jay, over by notices a framed PHOTO OF EDGAR, kneeling in the woods, p skin a deer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn. If he was this ugly before he was an alien...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, when I came to, he was gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he say anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! He asked for water. Sugar water, if I remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you taste her lemonade? Kay nods, puts on his sunglasses. Takes out another pair, Jay. Kay draws his neuralyzer. FLASH! Beatrice freezes, starin as if hypnotized. Kay takes Jay's glasses off and hands t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray Bans. (pulling off Jay's sunglasses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Beatrice. There was no alien, and the flash of light you saw in the sky wasn't a UFO. Swamp gas from a weather balloon was trapped in a thermal pocket and refracted the light from Venus --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa! That thing erases her memory, and you give her a new one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standard issue neuralyzer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's the best you can come up with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a more personal note, Beatrice, Edgar ran off with on old girlfriend. Go stay at your mother's for a few days and get over it. Decide you're better off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (butting in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and you're better off 'cause he never appreciated you anyway. In fact, you kicked him out, and now that he's gone, you ought to buy some new clothes, maybe hire a decorator or something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAY is in the hole where the ship landed, investigating. spectral analyzer over a section of scorched earth.  The colors.  Red. Then Yellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from up outside the hole)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Kay...when am I gonna get one of those memory things? The spectral analyzer turns blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you're ready. (re: analyzer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please -- not green. Purple. And then green. Kay closes his eyes and sits back, leaning against the di JAY leans over, staring down. Kay looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what alien life form leaves a green spectral trail?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait -- don't tell me -- that was the question on Final Jeopardy last night. AT THE CAR, Kay snatches up the radio handset and keys th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, into mic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zed, we have a bug. He turns off the radio and sighs. Jay stands next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna jump way past you and just guess that this is bad. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bugs thrive on carnage, Tiger.  They consume, infest and destroy. They live off the death and decay of other species.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So basically you have a racial problem with all insect-based life forms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, kid -- imagine a giant cockroach five times smarter than Albert Einstein, four times stronger than an ox, nine times meaner than hell, strutting his stuff around Manhattan Island in his brand new Edgar suit. Does that sound like fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a bug in town? Watch the morgues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSENBERG, the jewelry store owner, steps out of a cab in district, still carrying the ornate box and his beloved c Leshko's, a Russian diner. A moment later, the Orkin van pulls to a stop across the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSENBERG comes into the tiny restaurant, squinting in th darkness. At a table in the middle, he sees a man eating enormous, dignified, yet profoundly strange-looking man i fifties. Rosenberg walks carefully over to the table, but does not man (an ARQUILLIAN, and if we're eagle-eyed, we recognize on a "diplomatic mission" from passport control) rises fr steps forward, to face Rosenberg, who sets the ornate box Immediately, ROSENBERG'S CAT jumps on top of it. Rosenberg and the Arquillian stare at each other for a lo -- and then embrace each other. The embrace has an odd, f it, like mafiosi coming to a sitdown. They hold on, long both seemed choked with emotion. Finally, they break apart and take their seats. They spea alien tongue, which is subtitled. Rosenberg wipes away te

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late. The cab drivers on this planet are terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your majesty, you are in grave danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, and they overcharge you every time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, a bug landed here. We must get you off the planet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bug? He must know why I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think he does. (noticing the ornate box on the table)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what I think it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, just some diamonds for your children. Do we have time to eat? The Arquillian relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. I ordered you some pirogi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the kitchen, the Russian COOK slaps two orders of piro stainless steel counter --
